title: 109_s3742
content: The "Freight Rail Infrastructure Capacity Expansion Act of 2006" is also known as the "Freight Rail Capacity Expansion Credit" under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Freight Rail Capacity Expansion Credit allows for a 25 percent credit on the cost of new qualified freight rail infrastructure property and qualified locomotive property placed in service during the taxable year. New qualified freight rail infrastructure property includes property constructed or acquired by the taxpayer after the enactment of the act. The term 'new qualified freight rail infrastructure property' excludes property replacing existing property at the same location. 'Qualified freight rail infrastructure property' refers to property used for freight movement by rail, with costs chargeable to capital account. The term 'new qualified freight rail infrastructure property' includes railroad grading, tunnels, track, bridges, terminals, yards, buildings, fuel stations, docks, and equipment used exclusively for railroad operations. The term 'qualified freight rail infrastructure property' includes railroad signal, communication systems, intermodal transfer facilities, and terminals. Exclusions are land, rolling stock, and property used predominantly outside. The term 'qualified freight rail infrastructure property' includes railroad signal, communication systems, intermodal transfer facilities, and terminals. Exclusions are land, rolling stock, and property used predominantly outside the United States, except for property described in section 168(g)(4). Leased property is considered new if leased within 3 months after being placed in service. Qualified locomotive property refers to locomotives meeting the Environmental Protection Agency's standards. To qualify as 'qualified locomotive property,' a locomotive must meet EPA emission standards for locomotives, be owned or leased by a taxpayer meeting capacity expansion requirements, which entail having more total horsepower of locomotives at the end of the taxable year than the previous year. The determination for eligibility for the tax credit is based on reports prescribed by the Secretary and the Surface Transportation Board. Special rules apply to leasing locomotives, where only the lessor is eligible for the credit and total horsepower is determined based on all locomotives owned or leased by the lessee. Other definitions and special rules include the definition of 'railroad signal, communication, or other operating system.' The term 'railroad signal, communication, or other operating system' refers to devices used in railroad operations for safety and capacity improvement. The term 'intermodal transfer or transload facility or terminal' refers to facilities primarily used for transferring freight between rail and other modes of transportation. The cost of property for the tax credit cannot be used for other credits. The tax credit for qualified freight rail infrastructure and locomotive property includes basis adjustment and recapture provisions. The credit must be recaptured if the qualified locomotive property is sold within 5 years. This section does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2011. The tax credit for qualified freight rail infrastructure and locomotive property includes basis adjustment and recapture provisions. The credit must be recaptured if the qualified locomotive property is sold within 5 years. Section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include the freight rail capacity expansion credit under section 45N for taxable years beginning after the enactment of this clause. The tax credit for qualified freight rail infrastructure and locomotive property, including basis adjustment and recapture provisions, is now determined under section 45N. A clerical amendment has been made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 179E. ELECTION TO EXPENSE QUALIFIED FREIGHT RAIL INFRASTRUCTURE PROPERTY. Taxpayers can elect to deduct amounts paid for qualified freight rail infrastructure property as an expense in the year the property is placed in service. This election must be made for each class of property annually, following regulations set by the Secretary. Taxpayers can elect to deduct qualified freight rail infrastructure property expenses in the year it is placed in service, following regulations. The deduction applies to all property in the same class for that taxable year and does not affect property character for tax purposes. The deduction is allowed in computing minimum tax without adjustments, and the provision does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2011. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow deductions for expenditures under section 179E. Technical and clerical amendments are made to various sections of the Code to include 179E. Section 179E allows for the election to expense qualified freight rail infrastructure property. The effective date for the amendments made by sections 2 and 3 is for property placed in service after December 31, 2006.
